channel.title: Public Void Process [PI]
channel.description:
So, I followed this tutorial
[url=http://www.rune-server.org/runescape-development/rs2-server/tutorials/246259-how-stop-new-players-trading-certain-time-pi.html]New player Trading [PI][/url]
But it must not be compatible with my server and the time is all messed up and it resets etc, so i incorporated it with Public void process in client but its obviously executed a lot faster. How often is it executed so i can modify the time they have to wait to drop trade and pk.

item.title: Public Void Process [PI]
item.dc:creator: @Damoiscool Damoiscool
item.description:
@Damoiscool wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:8, topic:545688”][quote author=Damoiscool link=topic=664571.msg4442616#msg4442616 date=1407324137]
I see, so basically as long as you call the class and method it doesn’t matter, might put it in playerassistant then. thanks for your help

So this would take away 1 every second? I don’t need to call the method from elsewhere?

public void tradeTimer() { EventManager.getSingleton().addEvent(new Event() { @Override public void execute(EventContainer timer) { if (c.trade11 > 0) { c.trade11 -= 1; } else { c.trade11 = -1; } }, 1000); }
[/quote]
You should call the method when the player first logs in (So initialize in client.java).
And based on your code, you’re never ending the event.

public void tradeTimer() { EventManager.getSingleton().addEvent(new Event() { @Override public void execute(EventContainer timer) { if (c.trade11 > 0) { c.trade11 -= 1; } else { c.trade11 = -1; c.sendMessage("Your beginners protection has ended, you may now trade."); timer.stop(); } }, 1000); }[/quote]

You’re amazing.

Read full topic

item.title: Public Void Process [PI]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Damoiscool, post:7, topic:545688”]I see, so basically as long as you call the class and method it doesn’t matter, might put it in playerassistant then. thanks for your help

So this would take away 1 every second? I don’t need to call the method from elsewhere?

public void tradeTimer() { EventManager.getSingleton().addEvent(new Event() { @Override public void execute(EventContainer timer) { if (c.trade11 > 0) { c.trade11 -= 1; } else { c.trade11 = -1; } }, 1000); }[/quote]
You should call the method when the player first logs in (So initialize in client.java).
And based on your code, you’re never ending the event.

public void tradeTimer() { EventManager.getSingleton().addEvent(new Event() { @Override public void execute(EventContainer timer) { if (c.trade11 > 0) { c.trade11 -= 1; } else { c.trade11 = -1; c.sendMessage("Your beginners protection has ended, you may now trade."); timer.stop(); } }, 1000); }

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Damoiscool Damoiscool
item.description:
@Damoiscool wrote:

I see, so basically as long as you call the class and method it doesn’t matter, might put it in playerassistant then. thanks for your help

So this would take away 1 every second? I don’t need to call the method from elsewhere?

public void tradeTimer() { EventManager.getSingleton().addEvent(new Event() { @Override public void execute(EventContainer timer) { if (c.trade11 > 0) { c.trade11 -= 1; } else { c.trade11 = -1; } }, 1000); }

Read full topic

item.title: Public Void Process [PI]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Damoiscool, post:5, topic:545688”]Hm thanks I could probs modify that code to replace a whole bunch of shit. Thanks man! I take it that goes in client.java and the code goes under

You don’t have to put it in client.java, I’ve never understood why everyone thinks that. You put it in the class it fits with. You wouldn’t want to put item handling code in PlayerHandler, because that just wouldn’t make sense.

And yes, you want to put it under the start of the execute method.

Read full topic

item.title: Public Void Process [PI]
item.dc:creator: @Damoiscool Damoiscool
item.description:
@Damoiscool wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:4, topic:545688”][quote author=Damoiscool link=topic=664571.msg4442607#msg4442607 date=1407322427]

the method process in client.java (public void process() { ) runs every 600ms, or 1 server tick. Trading should not even touch that method. Trading should be done in a (from what I’m told, I’m too lazy to rewrite mine) container. How it’s currently handled is terrible, I can guarantee it.

If you want to add a timer, or a method to check how long it has been since the player joined. You should use an Event.
CycleEvents (it’s been released, google around for it) act based on server ticks, meaning if you set it to 5, it would run every 3000 milliseconds (5 x 6 = 30).
PI comes with an EventContainer/Handler that runs off milliseconds. So setting it to 5 would make it run every 5 milliseconds, and we don’t want that probably. I honestly wouldn’t use the EventHandler for anything more than a timer.

Confused a bit now. So you’re saying i shouldnt use process for the timer? This now all seems a lot more complex than making players wait 15 minutes before they can trade
[/quote]
Yes that is what I’m saying.
The timer doesn’t need to be executed every 600 milliseconds.

I’d use events to make it execute every second, or even every minute.

[code=java]
public void tradeTimer() {
EventManager.getSingleton().addEvent(new Event() {
@Override
public void execute(EventContainer timer) {

		}
	}, 1000);
}[/code]

The above code is an event that’s executed every 1000 ms (or 1 second).
All you have to do is add some code to make it work like a proper timer.[/quote]

Hm thanks I could probs modify that code to replace a whole bunch of shit. Thanks man! I take it that goes in client.java and the code goes under

Read full topic

item.title: Public Void Process [PI]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Damoiscool, post:3, topic:545688”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=664571.msg4442605#msg4442605 date=1407322126]
the method process in client.java (public void process() { ) runs every 600ms, or 1 server tick. Trading should not even touch that method. Trading should be done in a (from what I’m told, I’m too lazy to rewrite mine) container. How it’s currently handled is terrible, I can guarantee it.

If you want to add a timer, or a method to check how long it has been since the player joined. You should use an Event.
CycleEvents (it’s been released, google around for it) act based on server ticks, meaning if you set it to 5, it would run every 3000 milliseconds (5 x 6 = 30).
PI comes with an EventContainer/Handler that runs off milliseconds. So setting it to 5 would make it run every 5 milliseconds, and we don’t want that probably. I honestly wouldn’t use the EventHandler for anything more than a timer.
[/quote]

Confused a bit now. So you’re saying i shouldnt use process for the timer? This now all seems a lot more complex than making players wait 15 minutes before they can trade :/[/quote]
Yes that is what I’m saying.
The timer doesn’t need to be executed every 600 milliseconds.

I’d use events to make it execute every second, or even every minute.

[code=java]
public void tradeTimer() {
EventManager.getSingleton().addEvent(new Event() {
@Override
public void execute(EventContainer timer) {

		}
	}, 1000);
}[/code]

The above code is an event that’s executed every 1000 ms (or 1 second).
All you have to do is add some code to make it work like a proper timer.

Read full topic
